Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: An industrial facility has significant electromagnetic noise from heavy machinery. Computers are 60 meters from the network switch. What solution is recommended?
options: Category 6 STP or fiber optic cable
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: Category 6 STP (Shielded Twisted Pair) or fiber optic cable is recommended for industrial facilities with significant EMI. STP provides good EMI protection at lower cost, while fiber offers complete immunity to electromagnetic noise if budget allows.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: A university campus needs to connect buildings 500 meters apart with 1 Gbps links. What is the most appropriate solution?
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: Multimode fiber optic cable is most appropriate for 1 Gbps connections over 500 meters between campus buildings. Multimode fiber easily supports this distance and data rate, and it's more cost-effective than single-mode fiber for distances under 550 meters.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: A remote control application needs wireless communication within a single room, with minimal interference to other systems. Which technology is best?
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: Infrared is ideal for remote control applications within a single room. It provides short-range, line-of-sight communication in closed areas without interfering with other wireless systems, and is commonly used in TV remotes and similar devices.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: What is the main advantage of using a straight-through cable versus a crossover cable in modern networks?
options: Auto-MDIX technology makes crossover cables largely unnecessary
Straight-through cables have better EMI protection
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: Modern network devices with Auto-MDIX (Automatic Medium-Dependent Interface Crossover) technology can automatically detect and adapt to cable types, making crossover cables largely unnecessary. This is why crossover cables are now considered legacy technology.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: A network experiences frequent connection issues during thunderstorms. The network uses twisted pair cables in an area with frequent lightning. What improvement would help?
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: Replacing twisted pair with fiber optic cable would help because fiber is completely immune to electrical hazards including lightning-induced surges. Twisted pair cables have low immunity to electrical hazards, making them vulnerable during thunderstorms.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: A technician needs to test fiber optic connectivity. The cable is labeled with an orange jacket. What type of fiber is this?
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: An orange jacket (or aqua) indicates multimode fiber optic cable. Yellow jackets are used for single-mode fiber cables. This color coding standard helps technicians quickly identify the fiber type during installation and maintenance.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: An organization needs to connect two routers directly for redundancy. What cable configuration should be used?
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: Traditionally, a crossover cable (one end T568A, other end T568B) should be used for router-to-router connections. However, modern routers with Auto-MDIX can work with straight-through cables as they automatically detect and adjust to the cable type.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: A company wants to maximize bandwidth between data center core switches 20 meters apart. They need the highest possible speed. What should they use?
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: Single-mode fiber with high-speed transceivers provides the highest bandwidth capacity (up to 100 Gbps or more) for data center core switch connections. While the distance is short, fiber's superior bandwidth makes it ideal for maximum-speed backbone connections.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: A building automation system needs to connect sensors 3 km away from the control center. The system requires 10 Mbps bandwidth. What is the most economical choice?
options: Category 5e UTP with repeaters every 2 km
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: Category 5e UTP with repeaters placed every 2 km is the most economical choice for 10 Mbps over 3 km. While fiber would provide better performance, UTP with appropriate repeaters meets the bandwidth requirement at lower cost for this modest data rate.

Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.q: What is a key consideration when choosing between Category 5e and Category 6 cable for a new office installation?
options: Cat 5e supports 100 Mbps, Cat 6 supports 200 Mbps
Cat 5e is always cheaper regardless of performance needs
Cat 6 provides better future-proofing for higher speeds
Module 3: Physical Layer - Transmission.explanation: While Category 5e supports 125 Mbps and Category 6 supports 200 Mbps, the key consideration is future-proofing. Category 6 provides better performance margins and supports higher speeds (10 Gbps over shorter distances), making it a better investment for long-term installations despite higher initial cost.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the primary responsibility of the Data Link Layer?
options: Transferring frames from one node to a physically adjacent node over a link
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The Data Link Layer is responsible for transferring frames from one node to a physically adjacent node over a link. It handles direct node-to-node communication and ensures reliable data transfer between adjacent devices.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What are the two sublayers of the Data Link Layer?
options: Upper sublayer for data link control and Lower sublayer for media access
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The Data Link Layer is divided into two functionality-oriented sublayers: the upper sublayer responsible for data link control, and the lower sublayer responsible for resolving access to shared media. If the channel is dedicated, the lower sublayer is not needed.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Where is the Link Layer typically implemented?
options: In the operating system kernel only
On-chip or in the Network Interface Card (NIC)
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The Link Layer is implemented on-chip or in the Network Interface Card (NIC). This hardware-level implementation allows for efficient frame processing and direct interface with the physical transmission medium.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is framing in the context of the Data Link Layer?
options: Compressing data to reduce transmission time
Encapsulating datagrams into frames by adding headers and trailers
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Framing is the process of encapsulating datagrams into frames by adding headers and trailers. This packaging allows the Data Link Layer to add control information, error detection codes, and addressing information to the upper layer data.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What type of addresses are used in frame headers to identify source and destination?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: MAC (Media Access Control) addresses are used in frame headers to identify the source and destination devices. These are physical addresses burned into the Network Interface Card and operate at the Data Link Layer.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the purpose of flow control in the Data Link Layer?
options: To restrict the amount of data a sender can send before waiting for acknowledgment
To compress data for faster transmission
To route frames to the correct destination
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Flow control restricts the amount of data that the sender can send before waiting for acknowledgment from the receiver. This prevents buffer overflow at the receiver and ensures efficient data transmission.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does half-duplex communication mean?
options: Data can flow in both directions, but only one direction at a time
Data flows in one direction only
Data flows in both directions simultaneously
Data is transmitted in encrypted format
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Half-duplex communication allows data to flow in both directions, but only one direction at a time. This is in contrast to full-duplex, where data can flow in both directions simultaneously, and simplex, where data flows in only one direction.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Which Link Layer service is responsible for detecting corrupted frames?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Error control is responsible for detecting and recovering from errors that occur during frame transmission. It includes error detection mechanisms like parity checking, checksums, and CRC, as well as error recovery through retransmission.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the significance of understanding data boundaries in framing?
options: To know where headers can be read and frames begin and end
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Data boundaries must be known so that headers can be read correctly and the receiver can identify where each frame begins and ends. This is essential for proper frame processing and data extraction.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What are the three main types of framing methods?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The three main types of framing methods are byte (character) oriented protocols, bit-oriented protocols, and clock-based protocols. Each method uses different techniques to identify frame boundaries.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Which Link Layer protocol is mentioned as an example that uses different protocols over different links?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: WiFi and Ethernet are examples of different Link Layer protocols used over different types of links. A datagram may be transferred by different Link Layer protocols over different segments of its journey through the network.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: When is the lower sublayer of the Data Link Layer not needed?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: If the channel is dedicated (point-to-point), there is no need for the lower sublayer that resolves access to shared media. The lower sublayer is primarily needed when multiple devices share the same transmission medium.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does it mean that each Link Layer protocol provides different services?
options: They all operate at different speeds
Some may or may not provide reliable data transfer over the link
They use different cable types exclusively
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Each Link Layer protocol provides different services, meaning some may provide reliable data transfer over the link while others may not. The level of service depends on the specific requirements and design of the protocol.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What are the two main components added during framing?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: During framing, upper layer data is packed into frames by adding a header and a trailer. The header typically contains addressing and control information, while the trailer often contains error detection codes.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the broadcast MAC address?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The broadcast destination MAC address is FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF, where all bits are set to 1. This is a special case of the multicast address that is used to send frames to all devices on the local network segment.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is byte stuffing in byte-oriented protocols?
options: Adding extra bytes to increase frame size
Adding an extra ECS byte whenever there is a flag or escape character in the text
Removing unnecessary bytes from the frame
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Byte stuffing is the process of adding one extra ECS (Escape Character) byte whenever there is a flag or escape character in the text data. This prevents the receiver from mistaking data for control characters.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In byte-oriented protocols, what happens if the END flag appears in the actual data?
options: An ECS (Escape Character) is added before the flag
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: If the END flag appears in the actual data, a special character (ECS) is added before the flag to distinguish it from the actual END flag. This ensures that the receiver doesn't mistake data for the frame delimiter.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Which protocol commonly uses byte-oriented framing with byte stuffing?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) uses byte-oriented framing with byte stuffing. PPP is commonly used in modem connections, DSL, and cellular data connections for direct point-to-point communication.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In byte counting framing, how does the sender indicate the length of the data?
options: At the end of the frame
In the middle of the frame
At the beginning of each frame
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In byte counting framing, the sender inserts the length of the data in bytes at the beginning of each frame. The receiver extracts this length value and reads that many bytes to determine the frame boundaries.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is a significant problem with byte counting framing?
options: It requires too much processing power
If there is an error in the count field, frame synchronization is lost
It only works with ASCII characters
It is too slow for modern networks
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: If there is an error transmitting the count field in byte counting framing, the receiver will read the wrong number of bytes, causing frame synchronization to be lost. This can lead to misinterpretation of subsequent frames.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What flag pattern is used in HDLC (High-level Data Link Control) bit-oriented protocol?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: HDLC uses the flag pattern 01111110 to mark the start and end of frames. This distinctive pattern helps the receiver identify frame boundaries in bit-oriented protocols.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is bit stuffing in bit-oriented protocols?
options: Adding extra bits to increase frame size
Inserting a 0 after each sequence of five consecutive 1s followed by a 0
Removing unnecessary bits from the frame
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Bit stuffing involves inserting a 0 after each sequence of five consecutive 1s followed by a 0 in the data. This prevents the receiver from mistaking the pattern 0111110 for the HDLC flag (01111110).

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In clock-based framing protocols, how are frames distinguished?
options: By precise, fixed-time intervals with synchronized timing
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Clock-based protocols transmit frames at precise, fixed-time intervals and rely on synchronized timing between the sender and receiver. They typically use fixed-size frames and are common in synchronous networks.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Which type of network primarily uses clock-based framing protocols?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Clock-based framing is primarily used in high-speed, synchronous, point-to-point networks like SONET (Synchronous Optical Network). These networks rely on precise timing synchronization for frame delimitation.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A data sequence contains '11111101111110'. After bit stuffing for HDLC, what does the sequence become?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: After bit stuffing, the sequence becomes '1111110011111100'. A 0 is inserted after the first five 1s (making it 111110), and another 0 is inserted after the second sequence of five 1s (making it 111110), preventing confusion with the flag pattern.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What advantage does bit-oriented framing have over byte-oriented framing?
options: It is not restricted to 8-bit character boundaries
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Bit-oriented framing is not restricted to 8-bit character boundaries, making it more flexible for various data types. This allows for more efficient transmission of data that doesn't naturally align with byte boundaries.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In byte stuffing, what happens if the ECS (Escape Character) itself appears in the data?
options: Another ECS is added before it
It is replaced with a different character
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: If the ECS (Escape Character) itself appears in the data, another ECS is added before it. This recursive approach ensures that all special characters in the data are properly distinguished from control characters.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the primary characteristic of fixed-size frames in clock-based protocols?
options: All frames contain the same amount of data
Frames are transmitted at variable intervals
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In clock-based protocols with fixed-size frames, all frames contain the same amount of data and are transmitted at precise, fixed intervals. This regularity allows the receiver to synchronize based on timing rather than explicit delimiters.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Which framing method is most susceptible to errors in the length field?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Byte counting is most susceptible to errors in the length field. If the count field is corrupted, the receiver will read the wrong number of bytes, causing loss of frame synchronization and misinterpretation of subsequent data.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A network uses byte-oriented framing with START and END flags. What problem does byte stuffing solve?
options: Prevents confusion when flag patterns appear in the actual data
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Byte stuffing solves the problem of flag patterns appearing in the actual data. By adding escape characters before data that looks like flags, the receiver can distinguish between actual control flags and data that happens to match the flag pattern.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What are the two main aspects of error control in the Data Link Layer?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Error control consists of two main aspects: error detection (detecting corrupted frames) and error correction/recovery (handling detected errors). Detection methods include parity checks, checksums, and CRC, while recovery is typically handled through retransmission using ARQ protocols.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does ARQ stand for in error recovery protocols?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: ARQ stands for Automatic Repeat reQuest. ARQ protocols are used by the Data Link Layer to handle error recovery through retransmission when corrupted frames are detected.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does single-bit parity checking detect?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Single-bit parity checking can detect single-bit errors but is not reliable against burst errors (multiple consecutive bit errors). It sets a parity bit so there is an even or odd number of 1s in the data.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In even parity, how is the parity bit set?
options: Set so the total number of 1s (including parity bit) is even
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In even parity, the parity bit is set so that the total number of 1s, including the parity bit itself, is even. The receiver can then check if the received bits contain an even number of 1s to detect errors.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What advantage does two-dimensional parity have over single-bit parity?
options: It can detect and correct single-bit errors
It works only with even parity
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Two-dimensional parity can detect and correct single-bit errors, whereas single-bit parity can only detect them. It arranges data in a grid with both row and column parity bits, allowing identification of the exact error location.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: How many bit errors can two-dimensional parity detect?
options: All 1, 2, or 3-bit errors and some 4-bit errors
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Two-dimensional parity can detect all 1, 2, or 3-bit errors and some 4-bit errors. This makes it more robust than single-bit parity, though it still has limitations with certain error patterns.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does CRC stand for?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: CRC stands for Cyclic Redundancy Check. It is a more powerful error-detection coding method widely used in practice, including in Ethernet and 802.11 WiFi protocols.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Which error detection method is widely used in Ethernet and WiFi?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check) is widely used in Ethernet and 802.11 WiFi networks. It provides powerful error detection capabilities and can detect all burst errors less than r+1 bits, where r is the number of CRC bits.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In CRC, what does the variable 'G' represent?
options: The data bits to be transmitted
The generator bit pattern of r+1 bits
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In CRC, 'G' represents the generator bit pattern of r+1 bits. This generator polynomial is specified in the CRC standard and is used by both sender and receiver for computing and verifying the CRC.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: How does the CRC sender compute the CRC bits 'R'?
options: By adding all data bits together
By computing R = remainder of (D × 2^r) divided by G
By counting the number of 1s in the data
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The CRC sender computes R as the remainder of (D × 2^r) divided by G using modulo-2 arithmetic, where D is the data, r is the number of CRC bits, and G is the generator. This ensures that <D,R> is exactly divisible by G.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: At the CRC receiver, how is an error detected?
options: If the received frame is too short
If dividing the received frame by G produces a non-zero remainder
If the frame arrives too late
If the MAC address is incorrect
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The CRC receiver divides the received frame <D,R> by the generator G. If the division produces a non-zero remainder, an error is detected. A zero remainder indicates no error (or an undetectable error pattern).

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What type of burst errors can CRC detect?
options: All burst errors less than r+1 bits
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: CRC can detect all burst errors less than r+1 bits, where r is the number of CRC bits. This makes CRC particularly effective against burst errors, which are common in real-world transmission channels.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A 7-bit ASCII character with even parity has the bits '10110101'. Is there an error?
options: No error, the parity is correct
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: There is an error because the total number of 1s is 5 (odd), which violates even parity. For even parity, the total number of 1s including the parity bit must be even.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the main limitation of single-bit parity checking?
options: It requires too much computational power
It is not reliable against burst errors
It only works with text data
It increases frame size too much
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Single-bit parity checking is not reliable against burst errors. When multiple bits are corrupted in a burst, parity checking may fail to detect the errors, especially if an even number of bits are flipped.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In two-dimensional parity, if both a row parity error and column parity error are detected, what can be determined?
options: The total number of errors only
The exact location of a single-bit error
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: When both a row parity error and a column parity error are detected in two-dimensional parity, the intersection of the error row and error column identifies the exact location of a single-bit error, allowing it to be corrected.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What happens when a frame with detected errors is received at the Data Link Layer?
options: It is considered invalid and typically retransmitted using ARQ
It is passed to the Network Layer anyway
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: When an error is detected, the frame is considered invalid. The Data Link Layer handles this using retransmission through Automatic Repeat reQuest (ARQ) protocols, which request the sender to retransmit the corrupted frame.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Which error detection method provides the most powerful error detection capability?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check) provides the most powerful error-detection capability among the methods discussed. It can detect all burst errors less than r+1 bits and is widely used in modern networking protocols.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In a CRC calculation with data D=101110 and generator G=1001, what is appended to the data?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The CRC remainder R is appended to the data D to form the transmitted frame <D,R>. The receiver can then verify the frame by checking if <D,R> is divisible by G with zero remainder.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What arithmetic operation is used in CRC calculations?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: CRC uses modulo-2 arithmetic, which is equivalent to the XOR operation. In modulo-2 arithmetic, addition and subtraction are both performed as XOR, with no carry or borrow operations.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: If a received frame has the correct parity bit but still contains errors, what likely happened?
options: An even number of bits were flipped
The parity method is working perfectly
The receiver made a calculation error
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: If an even number of bits are flipped in transmission, the parity will still be correct, and the error will go undetected. This is a fundamental limitation of single-bit parity checking.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the purpose of flow control protocols?
options: To coordinate the number of frames sent before waiting for acknowledgment and prevent buffer overflow
To route frames to the correct destination
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Flow control protocols restrict and coordinate the number of frames a sender can transmit before waiting for acknowledgment from the receiver. This helps regulate data flow and prevents buffer overflow at the receiver.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In the simplest noiseless channel protocol, what does the sender do?
options: Waits for acknowledgment after each frame
Sends a sequence of frames without waiting for acknowledgment
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In the simplest noiseless channel protocol, the sender sends a sequence of frames without waiting for acknowledgment. This works only when the channel is completely reliable and the receiver can process frames as fast as they arrive.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does the Stop-and-Wait protocol require the sender to do?
options: Send one frame and wait for feedback before sending the next
Send frames only during specific time slots
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In the Stop-and-Wait protocol, the sender sends one frame and waits for feedback (acknowledgment) from the receiver. When the ACK arrives, the sender sends the next frame. This ensures flow control but has limited efficiency.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What additional feature does Stop-and-Wait ARQ have compared to simple Stop-and-Wait?
options: It uses sequence numbers and retransmission timers
It only works on noiseless channels
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Stop-and-Wait ARQ adds sequence numbers to frames and uses retransmission timers. The sender keeps a copy of the sent frame and retransmits it when the ACK timer expires, providing error recovery on noisy channels.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In Stop-and-Wait ARQ, what numbering system is used for sequence numbers?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Stop-and-Wait ARQ uses sequence numbers based on modulo-2 arithmetic, meaning only two sequence numbers (0 and 1) are used alternately. This is sufficient since only one frame is outstanding at any time.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does the acknowledgment number in Stop-and-Wait ARQ announce?
options: The sequence number of the next frame expected
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The acknowledgment number announces the sequence number of the next frame expected by the receiver. This implicitly acknowledges all frames with lower sequence numbers.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is a sliding window in flow control?
options: A physical component of the network
An abstract concept defining an imaginary box of frame sequence numbers
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The sliding window is an abstract concept defining an imaginary box that contains frame sequence numbers. It represents the frames that can be sent (send window) or received (receive window) at any given time.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In sliding window protocols, sequence numbers are based on what?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In sliding window protocols, sequence numbers are based on modulo-2^m arithmetic, where m determines the range of sequence numbers. This allows for wrapping of sequence numbers after reaching the maximum value.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the maximum send window size in a sliding window protocol with m-bit sequence numbers?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The maximum send window size is 2^m - 1, where m is the number of bits used for sequence numbers. This limitation is necessary to avoid ambiguity between new frames and retransmissions in the sequence number space.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: How is Stop-and-Wait ARQ related to Go-Back-N ARQ?
options: Stop-and-Wait is a special case of Go-Back-N with window size 1
Go-Back-N is faster in all cases
They use different sequence numbering systems
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Stop-and-Wait ARQ is a special case of Go-Back-N ARQ where the send window size is 1. This means only one frame can be outstanding at a time, which is the defining characteristic of Stop-and-Wait.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What happens when the send window slides in a sliding window protocol?
options: The window moves forward when valid acknowledgments arrive
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The send window can slide (move forward) one or more slots when valid acknowledgments arrive. This allows the sender to transmit new frames with sequence numbers that are now within the updated window.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the size of the receive window in basic Go-Back-N protocol?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In basic Go-Back-N protocol, the receive window size is 1. The receiver can only accept frames in order and does not buffer out-of-order frames, which simplifies implementation but reduces efficiency.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does pipelining mean in the context of sliding window protocols?
options: Sending frames through multiple physical cables
Sending multiple frames before waiting for acknowledgments
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Pipelining means sending multiple frames before waiting for acknowledgments. The sliding window allows multiple frames to be 'in flight' simultaneously, greatly improving channel utilization compared to Stop-and-Wait.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In Stop-and-Wait ARQ, why does the sender keep a copy of the sent frame?
options: To retransmit if the ACK timer expires
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The sender keeps a copy of the sent frame so it can retransmit the frame if the ACK timer expires (indicating the frame or its acknowledgment was lost). This copy is discarded once a valid acknowledgment is received.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What are the three variables in the send window concept?
options: Sf (first frame), Sn (next frame), and Ssize (window size)
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The send window has three variables: Sf (first outstanding frame), Sn (next frame to send), and Ssize (size of the window). These variables define which frames can be transmitted at any given time.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What type of acknowledgment does Go-Back-N use?
options: Cumulative ACK for correctly-received packets so far
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Go-Back-N uses cumulative acknowledgments, which acknowledge the highest in-order frame received. An ACK(n) indicates that all frames up to and including frame n have been correctly received.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In Go-Back-N, what happens when the receiver receives an out-of-order packet?
options: It buffers the packet and waits for missing packets
It discards the packet and resends the last ACK
It forwards the packet to the upper layer
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In Go-Back-N, when the receiver receives an out-of-order packet, it discards the packet (no buffering) and resends the ACK for the last correctly received in-order frame. This simplifies the receiver but can lead to unnecessary retransmissions.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: When a timeout occurs in Go-Back-N with window size N, what does the sender do?
options: Retransmits the timed-out packet and all higher sequence number packets in the window
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: When a timeout occurs in Go-Back-N, the sender retransmits the timed-out packet (frame n) and all higher sequence number packets currently in the window. This 'go back' behavior gives the protocol its name.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In Go-Back-N with window size 4, if ACK(1) is received, what happens to the window?
options: The window moves forward to begin at frame 2
The window stays in the same position
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: When ACK(n) is received in Go-Back-N, the window moves forward to begin at frame n+1. So receiving ACK(1) moves the window to begin at frame 2, allowing new frames to be transmitted.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the main disadvantage of Go-Back-N protocol?
options: It is too complex to implement
It may retransmit frames that were received correctly but out of order
It only works on noiseless channels
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The main disadvantage of Go-Back-N is that it may retransmit frames that were actually received correctly but were out of order. Since the receiver discards out-of-order frames, all frames from the error point onward must be retransmitted.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: How does Selective Repeat differ from Go-Back-N in terms of acknowledgments?
options: Selective Repeat individually acknowledges all correctly received packets
They use the same ACK mechanism
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Selective Repeat individually acknowledges all correctly received packets, whereas Go-Back-N uses cumulative acknowledgments. This allows the sender in Selective Repeat to know exactly which frames need retransmission.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What does the Selective Repeat receiver do with out-of-order packets?
options: Forwards them to upper layer out of order
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The Selective Repeat receiver buffers out-of-order packets as needed. This allows it to avoid discarding correctly received frames, reducing unnecessary retransmissions compared to Go-Back-N.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In Selective Repeat, when a frame times out, what does the sender retransmit?
options: Only the frame with no ACK
The frame and all subsequent frames
Nothing, it waits for more timeouts
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In Selective Repeat, when a frame times out, the sender retransmits only that specific frame (the one with no ACK). This selective retransmission is more efficient than Go-Back-N's approach of retransmitting all subsequent frames.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A Go-Back-N sender with window size 4 sends frames 0, 1, 2, 3. Frame 2 is lost. What frames need to be retransmitted?
options: Frames 2, 3, and any new frames sent before timeout
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In Go-Back-N, when frame 2 times out, the sender must retransmit frame 2 and all higher sequence number frames in the window (frame 3, plus any additional frames like 4, 5 that may have been sent before the timeout was detected).

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: Why might Go-Back-N generate duplicate acknowledgments?
options: Due to transmission errors in ACKs
When out-of-order packets arrive, the receiver resends the last in-order ACK
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Go-Back-N may generate duplicate acknowledgments because when out-of-order packets arrive (after a frame is lost), the receiver discards them and resends the ACK for the last correctly received in-order frame each time.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In Selective Repeat, if frames 0, 1, 2, 3 are sent and frame 2 is lost but frame 3 is received, what does the receiver do?
options: Forwards frame 3 to upper layer immediately
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In Selective Repeat, the receiver buffers frame 3 and sends ACK(3) even though frame 2 is missing. When frame 2 eventually arrives, the receiver can deliver both frames 2 and 3 in order to the upper layer.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What is the main advantage of Selective Repeat over Go-Back-N?
options: Avoids unnecessary retransmissions of correctly received frames
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The main advantage of Selective Repeat is that it avoids unnecessary retransmissions of frames that were received correctly but out of order. By buffering these frames, only the missing frames need to be retransmitted.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: In Go-Back-N, what timer mechanism is typically used?
options: Single timer for the oldest in-flight packet
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Go-Back-N typically uses a single timer for the oldest in-flight packet. When this timer expires, all frames from that point onward are retransmitted. This simplifies timer management compared to maintaining separate timers.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A Selective Repeat receiver receives frames 0, 1, 3, 4, 5 (frame 2 is missing). What can it deliver to the upper layer?
options: Only frames 0 and 1 until frame 2 arrives
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: The Selective Repeat receiver can deliver only frames 0 and 1 to the upper layer because frame 2 is missing. Frames 3, 4, 5 are buffered. Once frame 2 arrives, all buffered frames can be delivered in order.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: What happens in Go-Back-N when ACK(2) arrives at the sender?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: In Go-Back-N, ACK(2) is a cumulative acknowledgment that acknowledges frames 0, 1, and 2. This means all frames up to and including frame 2 have been correctly received, and the sender can remove them from its buffer.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A network uses Stop-and-Wait ARQ with a 100 ms round-trip time and 1000-bit frames at 1 Mbps. What is the channel utilization?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Channel utilization = (transmission time) / (transmission time + RTT). Transmission time = 1000 bits / 1 Mbps = 1 ms. Utilization = 1/(1+100) ≈ 1%. Stop-and-Wait is very inefficient for high bandwidth-delay product networks.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A company experiences frequent frame corruption on their network. Which combination of techniques should they implement?
options: CRC for error detection and ARQ for error recovery
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: To handle frequent frame corruption, the company should implement CRC for powerful error detection combined with ARQ protocols for error recovery through retransmission. This provides both detection and correction capabilities.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A satellite link has a 270 ms one-way delay. Which flow control protocol would be most efficient?
options: Go-Back-N or Selective Repeat with large window
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: For high-delay links like satellites (540 ms RTT), Go-Back-N or Selective Repeat with large windows are most efficient. They allow many frames to be in transit, maintaining high channel utilization despite the long delay.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A network designer must choose between Go-Back-N and Selective Repeat for a high-error-rate wireless link. Which is better and why?
options: Selective Repeat because it avoids retransmitting correctly received frames
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Selective Repeat is better for high-error-rate links because it only retransmits frames that were actually lost or corrupted, not correctly received out-of-order frames. This significantly reduces unnecessary retransmissions compared to Go-Back-N.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A frame arrives with calculated CRC bits that match the received CRC. What can be concluded?
options: The frame is probably error-free, but some error patterns could go undetected
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: While matching CRC bits strongly indicate the frame is error-free, CRC cannot detect all possible error patterns. Some rare combinations of errors can produce the same CRC, though this probability is very low for well-designed CRC polynomials.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A protocol needs to transmit real-time video where occasional frame loss is acceptable but retransmissions cause delays. What approach is best?
options: Simple protocol without ARQ, accepting some losses
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: For real-time video where delays from retransmissions are more problematic than occasional losses, a simple protocol without ARQ is best. This accepts some frame losses but avoids retransmission delays that would disrupt real-time playback.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A network administrator notices that Go-Back-N is retransmitting many correctly received frames. What modification would help?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Switching to Selective Repeat would help because it buffers out-of-order frames and only retransmits specifically those frames that are lost or corrupted, avoiding the unnecessary retransmissions characteristic of Go-Back-N.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: For a protocol using 3-bit sequence numbers, what is the maximum window size for proper operation?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: With 3-bit sequence numbers (m=3), the sequence number space is 2^3=8. The maximum window size should be 2^m - 1 = 7 frames to avoid ambiguity between sequence numbers of new frames and retransmissions.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A point-to-point synchronous optical network needs precise timing for frame delimitation. Which framing method is most appropriate?
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Clock-based framing is most appropriate for synchronous optical networks like SONET that require precise timing. These networks use fixed-size frames transmitted at precise intervals with synchronized timing between sender and receiver.

Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.q: A wireless sensor network has limited processing power and memory. Between Go-Back-N and Selective Repeat, which is more suitable?
options: Selective Repeat because it's more efficient
Go-Back-N because it has simpler receiver implementation with no buffering
Module 4: Data Link Layer - Control Prot.explanation: Go-Back-N is more suitable for resource-constrained devices because its receiver implementation is simpler with no buffering requirement (window size of 1). Selective Repeat requires more memory for buffering out-of-order frames and more complex processing logic.
